TypeSignature.Value: .class public interface auto ansi abstract UI2 implements class Microsoft.Office.Interop.InfoPath.SemiTrust.UI

Docs.summary: This type is a wrapper for a COM interface implemented by a coclass that is required by managed code for COM interoperability. To access the members specified by this interface, use the type that wraps the coclass that implements this interface. For information about that type, including usage, remarks, and examples, see.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Alert(string bstrAlertString) cil managed

Docs.summary: Displays a message box with a custom text message in a Microsoft InfoPath form.

remarks.para: The Alert method displays a simple message box that uses an information icon and an OK button. Only the text in the message box can be customized.
Note: In Visual C# code, carriage returns can be inserted into the text of the custom message by using the standard \n characters.
Important: This member can be accessed only by forms running in the same domain as the currently open form, or by forms that have been granted cross-domain permissions.

example.para: In the following example, the Alert method of the object is used to display a message box:
example.code: thisXDocument.UI.Alert("Custom message text goes here.");

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance valuetype Microsoft.Office.Interop.InfoPath.SemiTrust.XdConfirmChoice Confirm(string bstrPrompt, valuetype Microsoft.Office.Interop.InfoPath.SemiTrust.XdConfirmButtons lButtons) cil managed
Public Function Confirm (bstrPrompt As String, lButtons As XdConfirmButtons) As XdConfirmChoice

Docs.param: The text message to be displayed.
Specifies the number and type of buttons to display. You may specify any of the values of the enumeration.
Docs.summary: Displays a message box with buttons for input from a user.

remarks.para: Important: This member can be accessed only by forms running in the same domain as the currently open form, or by forms that have been granted cross-domain permissions.

example.para: In the following example, the Confirm method of the object is used to display a dialog box with Yes and No buttons:
example.code: thisXDocument.UI.Confirm("Do you wish to continue?", XdConfirmButtons.xdYesNo);

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetSaveAsDialogFileName(string bstrFileName) cil managed

Docs.param: The file name of the form supplied to the Save As dialog box.
Docs.summary: Sets the default file name for a form in the Save As dialog box.

remarks.para: If the argument is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic), "Form" is used as the file name. The SetSaveAsDialogFileName method may be used in conjunction with the method.
Important: This member can be accessed only by forms running in the same domain as the currently open form, or by forms that have been granted cross-domain permissions.

example.para: In the following example, the SetSaveAsDialogFileName method of the object is used to set the default file name for the "Save As" dialog box:

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SetSaveAsDialogLocation(string bstrLocation) cil managed

Docs.param: The location, expressed as a URL, at which the Save As dialog box starts browsing.
Docs.summary: Sets the initial location at which the Save As dialog starts to browse when it is opened.

remarks.para: The location specified must be an absolute path and it should not include a file name. InfoPath handles invalid paths, however, and no error message is generated if an invalid path is specified for the argument. The SetSaveAsDialogLocation method may be used in conjunction with the method.
Important: This member can be accessed only by forms running in the same domain as the currently open form, or by forms that have been granted cross-domain permissions.

example.para: In the following example, the SetSaveAsDialogLocation method of the object is used to set the initial location for the "Save As" dialog:

MemberSignature.Value: public void ShowMailItem (string bstrTo, string bstrCC, string bstrBCC, string bstrSubject, string bstrBody);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ShowMailItem(string bstrTo, string bstrCC, string bstrBCC, string bstrSubject, string bstrBody) cil managed
Public Sub ShowMailItem (bstrTo As String, bstrCC As String, bstrBCC As String, bstrSubject As String, bstrBody As String)
public: void ShowMailItem(System::String ^ bstrTo, System::String ^ bstrCC, System::String ^ bstrBCC, System::String ^ bstrSubject, System::String ^ bstrBody);
abstract member ShowMailItem : string * string * string * string * string -> unit

Docs.param: The e-mail address to send the e-mail message to.
The e-mail address to copy the e-mail message to.
The e-mail address to blind copy the e-mail message to.
The subject of the e-mail message.
The body text of the e-mail message.
Docs.summary: Creates an e-mail message in the default e-mail editor and attaches the currently open Microsoft InfoPath form to the message.

remarks.para: After the e-mail message is created, the default e-mail editor will display the e-mail message; users can then inspect and edit the e-mail message before sending it. The ShowMailItem method will return an error if no e-mail editing program is available.
Note: The ShowMailItem method does not send the e-mail messages it creates; users must manually send the e-mail messages.
You can also use the object or object to programmatically create e-mail messages.
Important: This member can be accessed only by forms running in the same domain as the currently open form, or by forms that have been granted cross-domain permissions.

example.para: In the following example, the ShowMailItem method of the object is used to create a custom e-mail message:
example.code: thisXDocument.UI.ShowMailItem("someone@example.com", "", "", "Updated Form", "Here is the updated form that you requested.");

MemberSignature.Value: public object ShowModalDialog (string bstrName, object varArguments, object varHeight, object varWidth, object varTop, object varLeft);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance object ShowModalDialog(string bstrName, object varArguments, object varHeight, object varWidth, object varTop, object varLeft) cil managed
Public Function ShowModalDialog (bstrName As String, varArguments As Object, varHeight As Object, varWidth As Object, varTop As Object, varLeft As Object) As Object

public: System::Object ^ ShowModalDialog(System::String ^ bstrName, System::Object ^ varArguments, System::Object ^ varHeight, System::Object ^ varWidth, System::Object ^ varTop, System::Object ^ varLeft);
abstract member ShowModalDialog : string * obj * obj * obj * obj * obj -> obj
MemberSignature.Usage: uI2.ShowModalDialog (bstrName, varArguments, varHeight, varWidth, varTop, varLeft)

Docs.param: The name of the .html file used for the modal dialog box.
Specifies the arguments to use when displaying the modal dialog box. Can be any type of value, including an array of values.
Sets the height of the modal dialog box.
Sets the width of the modal dialog box.
Sets the top position of the modal dialog box relative to the upper left corner of the desktop.
Sets the left position of the modal dialog box relative to the upper left corner of the desktop.
Docs.summary: Displays a custom modal dialog box in a Microsoft InfoPath form.
Docs.returns: An object that specifies how to display the modal dialog box.

remarks.para: The ShowModalDialog method allows you to display custom dialog boxes to users as they fill out a fully trusted form. Custom dialog boxes are implemented as .html files created in any type of HTML editor, such as Microsoft FrontPage. You can use scripting code in a custom dialog box that interacts with the InfoPath object model if you pass objects to the custom dialog box using the parameter.

To use a custom dialog box in an InfoPath form, you must first add the .html file of the custom dialog box to the form's set of resource files by using the Resource Files dialog box. The Resource Files dialog box is available from the Tools menu in design mode. After you have added the custom dialog box file to the form, you can use the ShowModalDialog method to display it.

Although the ShowModalDialog method can only be used in fully trusted forms, you can create a custom dialog box in standard forms using the showModalDialog method of the Dynamic HTML (DHTML) object model if you have an HTML task pane specified in your form, or by using a Windows form.

Important: This member can be accessed only by forms opened from a form template that has been configured to run with full trust using the Security and Trust category of the Form Options dialog box. This member requires full trust for the immediate caller and cannot be used by partially trusted code. For more information, see "Using Libraries from Partially Trusted Code" on MSDN.

example.para: In the following example, the ShowModalDialog method of the object is used to display a custom dialog box. Note that the object is passed to the custom dialog box using the parameter.
For information on how to use the ShowModalDialog box method, see How to: Display Alerts and Dialog Boxes (InfoPath 2003 Object Model).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ShowSignatureDialog() cil managed

Docs.summary: Displays the Microsoft InfoPathDigital Signatures dialog box.

remarks.para: The ShowSignatureDialog method can be used only in forms that have been enabled for digital signing. The method will return an error if used in a form that is not enabled for digital signing.
Important: This member can be accessed only by forms running in the same domain as the currently open form, or by forms that have been granted cross-domain permissions.

example.para: In the following example, the ShowSignatureDialog method of the object is used to display the Microsoft InfoPath Digital Signatures dialog box:
